docs.lead_paragraph: The collapse of an elevator tower at a Times Square construction site on Tuesday continued to disrupt the manic routine of midtown Manhattan yesterday, as dozens of local shops remained shuttered, hundreds of police officers directed traffic away from blocked-off streets and multitudes of tourists and workers marveled, muttered and adapted. Adaptation will continue to be the requisite approach to life in the epicenter of New York, city officials say. Many shops and some streets will stay closed at least until tomorrow, while workers raise a 700-by-100-foot curtain around the broken scaffolding that runs up the north face of the Conde Nast Building, on Broadway between 42d and 43d Streets. The reinforced nylon curtain will allow workers to take apart the scaffolding under safe conditions, a process that could take weeks.

headline.main: After Collapse, Midtown Stress Hits New Highs
headline.kicker: CONSTRUCTION COLLAPSE IN TIMES SQUARE: THE OVERVIEW

docs.abstract: Construction accident in Times Square area continues to disrupt manic routine of midtown Manhattan; dozens of local shops remain shuttered, and hundreds of police officers direct traffic away from blocked-off streets; many shops and some streets will stay closed at least until after workers raise giant reinforced nylon curtain around broken scaffolding running up north face of Conde Nast Building; netting is supposed to be in place by weekend, but taking apart scaffolding under safe conditions could take weeks; Mayor Giuliani calls on developer, Durst Orgn, and general contractor, Tishman Construction Corp, to compensate many businesses forced to shut down because of accident; two companies issue statement apologizing for inconveniences and announcing plan to speed payment of insurance claims; say they set up fund for individuals left homeless; only vehicles allowed in barricaded Times Square are squad cars, fire engines and bus labeled Interagency Command Center; photos (M)
docs.snippet: The collapse of an elevator tower at a Times Square construction site on Tuesday continued to disrupt the manic routine of midtown Manhattan yesterday, as dozens of local shops remained shuttered, hundreds of police officers directed traffic away...
docs.section_name: Front Page; New York and Region

docs.lead_paragraph: Nearly a year after bringing fraud charges against three executives with the Columbia/HCA Healthcare Corporation, Federal prosecutors filed a new indictment yesterday naming a fourth company executive as a participant in an illegal scheme to defraud Federal health programs. The fourth executive, Carl Lynn Dick, finance director for Columbia's Central Eastern division, was charged in the superseding indictment handed up by a Federal grand jury in Tampa, Fla. There was little surprising in the new charges: prosecutors earlier this year had announced that they would file new charges in the case, and allegations against Mr. Dick had been raised in a Government affidavit in support of a raid on Columbia last year.

headline.main: A New Indictment Is Issued In the Columbia/HCA Case

docs.abstract: Federal prosecutors file new indictment against Columbia/HCA Healthcare Corp, naming fourth executive, Carl Lynn Dick, as participant in illegal scheme to defraud Federal health programs; charges offer new details about what prosecutors believe was complex scheme to cheat programs like Medicare through misrepresentation of certain costs at Columbia's Fawcett Memorial Hospital in Port Charlotte, Fla; new charges also describe role played in preparation of cost reports by Fawcett's accountants, KPMG Peat Marwick; acccounting firm has not been charged with any wrongdoing (M)
docs.snippet: Nearly a year after bringing fraud charges against three executives with the Columbia/HCA Healthcare Corporation, Federal prosecutors filed a new indictment yesterday naming a fourth company executive as a participant in an illegal scheme to defraud...

docs.lead_paragraph: Medicare health maintenance organizations competing for new enrollees appear to work at selling themselves to healthier potential customers, according to a study released by the Kaiser Family Foundation in Menlo Park, Calif. The study was based on an analysis by Porter Novelli, a unit of Omnicom Group, of marketing practices by H.M.O.'s in Cleveland, Los Angeles, Miami and New York. Researchers reviewed ads in 169 newspapers and on 129 television stations and observed and analyzed 21 marketing seminars to assess the marketing techniques used by H.M.O.'s to attract Medicare enrollees.

headline.main: Study Says H.M.O.'s Pitch to Hale Elderly

docs.abstract: Study by Kaiser Family Foundation shows medicare health maintenance organizatiosn competing for new enrollees appear to work at selling themselves to healthier potential customers; study concludes marketing efforts seem to be aimed at physically active elderly rather than full range of Medicare beneficiaries (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Greenspan Warns Investors About End to Exuberance Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, warned investors during his appearance before the House Banking subcommittee not to assume that the good times on Wall Street would last forever. But he could not predict when the exuberance would end and a correction start. His comments helped send stock market gauges lower. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 61.28 points, to 9,128.91. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index closed down 0.99 at 1,164.08. The Nasdaq composite index dropped 9.39, to 1,969.75. [Page D6.]

docs.lead_paragraph: Oxford Health Plans, the troubled company that once held great promise for the future of managed care, is warning doctors that it must raise premiums and reduce how much it pays doctors and hospitals in order to make money. In a letter sent to doctors on Monday, Norman C. Payson, Oxford's new chief executive, outlined the steps the company plans to take. Oxford is considering shrinking the size of its hospital network and will try to more aggressively discourage members from going to doctors outside its network.

headline.main: Oxford Health To Raise Rates And Cut Fees

docs.abstract: Oxford Health Plans, troubled company that once held great promise for future of managed care, is warning doctors that it must raise premiums and reduce how much it pays doctors and hospitals in order to make money; Oxford's new chief executive, Norman C Payson, in letter sent to doctors, outlines steps company plans to take; Oxford is considering shrinking size of its hospital network and will try to more aggressively discourage members from going to doctors outside its network; chart (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: One day earlier, the workers from the South Coast Hospice had at least brought food. But today they had only bad news to deliver. They had not been able to find anyone willing to donate a coffin for Ennie Gambushe's daughter, Mercy, who had died of AIDS. Nor had they come up with the $18 needed for a traditional burial.

headline.main: A Post-Apartheid Agony: AIDS on the March

docs.abstract: AIDS epidemic in South Africa is now one of fastest growing in world; experts say country missed unique opportunity it had to prevent kind of explosion of AIDS cases now ravaging rest of Africa; South Africa had health system better than any other on continent, and for years it was protected by apartheid's isolationism from major exposure to infection; but country was absorbed by its transition from white supremacist rule in early 1990's, and no one paid much attention to halting unprotected sex; experts say Government's efforts to combat epidemic have been slow and marred by scandal; now, about 12 percent of all adults in South Africa are infected with HIV; rate of infection is highest, at 20 percent, among women in their 20's; for now, virus is most prevalent among South Africa's poor blacks; photos; map; charts (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: Although she has never run for office before, Margarethe Cammermeyer would seem to have a resume tailor-made for politics: she is a mother of four, a nurse with a doctoral degree, a retired Army colonel and a Vietnam War veteran who won the Bronze Star. But the one thing that voters in this fast-growing district north of Seattle are sure to hear about Ms. Cammermeyer in her run for Congress is that she also is gay. Or, as Representative Jack Metcalf, the Republican incumbent, called her in a recent mailing, ''a controversial lesbian.''

headline.main: Lesbian in Uphill Race for Congress

docs.abstract: Margarethe Cammermeyer, Democrat seeking Congressional seat in Washington State, would seem to have resume tailor-made for politics; she is mother of four, nurse, retired Army colonel and Vietnam War veteran who won Bronze Star; one thing voters in Everett, fast-growing district near Seattle, are sure to hear about Cammermeyer in her run for Congress is that she also is gay, or as Republican incumbent Jack Metcalf called her in recent mailing 'a controversial lesbian'; map; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: The concerns of privacy groups over the Clinton Administration's proposal for a national health identifier, a computer code used to create a national data base of every citizen's medical history, are not overstated (front page, July 20). In my research on two books on the Third Reich, I was struck that the Nazis used a German equivalent of a national health insurance card to identify Jewish citizens.

headline.main: Better Health Care, Or Big Brother?

docs.abstract: Gerald Posner letter says Clinton Administation's proposal for national data base containing every citizen's medical history should not be instituted without strong guarantees of patient privacy (July 20 article)
